review_title: It has some pros and cons
pros: Great team of people to work with, flexi time and place to learn skills within your role. Healthy team environment with staff from different backgrounds, nationalities and experience. There is a lot of great potential within different departments. It is a really nice place to work and you feel very supported within your role duties. Very nice and quite new office. Great place to learn, very good training and organization mission.
cons: They have an old fashioned managerial style and it is quite hierarchical. It takes a lot of effort for them to open to new ways of working and actually implementing it. Lack of investment in new resources to adapt to quite clunky tools and very high workload, will take a lot time and effort to receive very much needed resources. Salary reviews highly needed, they are proposed but can take years. Staff needs more support in flexibility to work remotely outside of the prime location, specially being an international organization with people from all over the countru and globe taking into account the current Covid crisis. Not a lot of professional development offered after training.

pros: Good salary, great offices, amazing colleagues.
cons:
I worked here for just a decade, and I rarely experienced the kind of support my role needed from line management. At least in my department, line managers are oblivious to the needs of their employees, they just go from meeting to meeting and barely touch base with them. Some of them don’t even know what we do! (And they’re not prepared to listen either)
But of course, they want all the credit for our achievements and will patronise us on a daily basis. They change the goal posts daily, there’s no transparency in most of the processes they manage and the CAO seems completely unaware of this. Very toxic culture which drains employees and leave them very unmotivated.

pros: Flexible working hours, good mission statement, staff are generally very nice people.
cons: False promises of escalating rewarding pay, poor training, no development of staff beyond some basic courses, doesn't invest in its people. Very out-dated management, poor morale across the department, ideas get stonewalled, almost everything is blamed on cost. Company thinks it's at the leading edge of technology, it is in fact falling behind as the many layers middle management would not recognise cutting edge if it were handed to them on a plate. Very difficult to progress, talent isn't recognised at all. The IPDR and pay structure is awful, demoralising and a waste of staff time, like a good prison, time served seems to be the only thing that matters. It will take you a long time to get anywhere as managers look out for each other, regardless of how talented you are, jobs are either grossly underpaid or overpaid, depending in which decade you started. All in all, a very poor working environment.

review_title: It's a mission driven organisation with a truly international agenda, non-profit status and some progressive ideas.
pros: You have to believe in the mission, which is primarily about promoting peace through education that aims to raise intercultural awareness and understanding. If you're a supporter of the aims of the UN, then it may be the place for you, as it offers a truly international environment and gains support from new quarters each day.
cons: Elitist DNA of board members and major donors threatens to overwhelm positive aspects of the mission. Tendency to pay lip service to mission and values is a sad reflection on the vision of the founders.

review_title: Struggling to cope with growth and to overcome institutionalised elitism
pros:
Opportunity to work internationally
Positive and engaged community of students and teachers
cons:
Poor planning for growth has resulted in unreliable and out-dated systems and panic about the future
Lack of effective leadership causes conflicting priorities amongst departments and silo working
Lack of understanding about the challenges the organisation faces from competitors, resulting in poor business decisions on new products and services
Questionable morality of the programme overall - tendency to promote elitist world-view which lacks empathy for those who under-achieve through no fault of their own

review_title: Certain members  of the small Senior Leadership team are an embarrassment to their colleagues
cons: Senior leadership team dictate and seek to control everything. Two select individuals, CFO and CDO, are Trumpesque in their desire to protect their reputations, control the narrative and eliminate dissent. They promote toxic interdepartmental conflict in an ‘attack is the best form of defence’ mindset. The organization, progress and most importantly, the mental health of their staff bears the burden of their egotistical posturing.
